captions.text:
The thing I love most
in the world.

Vivica, get off
the line now!

A hooker. All right,
you killed a hooker.

Get your hands
on some bleach,

Some hydrogen peroxide
and a shitload of lime.

I mean,
that's probably not
even her real name.

Man, don't scare me
like that!

Screw tivo.
I'm way beyond tivo.

Last I checked, they hadn't
hooked it up, though.

Hadn't hooked it up?
No tivo?

Where have you
moved on to?

comments.author: Christopher Jackson

comments.text:
Yeah... that's been mentioned a couple times. I'm objective to humour, and 
though that comment is cute & all - certainly not *LMAO* worthy... just my 
humble opinion - it's even a tad *over-compensation* in an unsettled 
feeling that they needed to pander to potentially thin-skinned black 
audiences of the movie would find Robert Downey's *black-man* performance 
as a slight or all-out offensive character directed at the black population 
altogether. So, I suppose, in the name of *fairness* & *white-insults*, 
they seemed to balance Robert Downey JR'S attempts at being an Australian 
playing an African-American soldier in a movie that was fictional, but 
ende-up being a real fictional movie in the absurd process. Nonetheless, 
Robert Downey Jr. stole the movie with his performance. Without him, the 
movie would have been devoid of the most comically, truly best-acted 
character in the movie - right alongside Ben Stiller going *Full Retard* 
for 'Simple Jack'.
Terrific Robert Downey Jr. Performance - I watched this movie repeatedly 
just because of Robert Downey JR's wonderful acting display!
I am forced to consider he played the character of a 'black 
African-American soldier' better, & definitely more humorous than an 
authentic *black man* playing the character of an actor of a 'black 
soldier' in the jungle wars of Vietnam/Cambodia.
What a hilarious success Robert Downey JR's "Australian blue-eyed, blonde 
hair, Aussie-accented, fair-whit-skinned" playing so convincingly an 
"African-American southern black soldier" - so tastefully humorous, & with 
several *LoL* moments. 
Just a tremendous performance by RDJ to complete his amazing talented & 
skilled imitation of of what a *real southern Afro-American black soldier* 
would act like, sound like and truly intangible have a demeanour that can 
convince, persuade, & ultimately be a funnier character than 'the real 
thing'.
Remember - it's not the colour of your skin, the presuppositions of 
demeanour, or the realization of what 'one' & inevitably 'many' have gone 
through by way of cold-heartless experiences - Robert Downey JR provided an 
acting achievement that crosses the ethnic, colour, & religious standpoints 
that are pre-determined by stereotypes themselves.
Congratulations Robert Downey JR for an outstanding acting performance! ; )
